And movie was not really worth to watch.

It's combination of different genres, styles, tones and settings doesn't always work but Prisoners of the Ghostland is still an insane and unique film that's tons of fun, extremely colourful, really funny and hypnotic.Nicolas Cage gives a perfect lead performance that starts of as the least unhinged character somehow and then unleashes all of the classic Cage craziness as it goes along. Sofia Boutella gives a great performance as the heart of the film and Bill Moseley is really good, which cancels out some of the weaker and more annoying smaller supporting performances.Sion Sono's direction is fantastic, the film is consistently bold and weird and culminates in a really fun, stylish and gleefully violent final battle. The music by Joseph Trapanese is also really good and adds to the overall insanity.
The movie is absurd. Jumping from Western to zombie to samurai, it's a weird ride.Not great.

reviews.review_title: Nick cage must owe some serious drug money
reviews.content: This is just bad really really bad like a fever dream come to life anyone that gives it more than a star worked on the movie and to the reviewer that said any rating this poorly is making stuff up no no we are not this movie sucks that bad and at this point in his career nick cage is acting in any goofy movie for cocaine.

I have seen quite a few Sion Sono movies and would call myself a fan, and think cage Nic Cage has been a few great sleeper hits in the last few years too so I was pretty hopeful for this. I saw it at at sneak preview screening at a festival tonight.Cage is a bank robber who is given a mission to retrieve Bill Mosley's "granddaughter" from a post apocalyptic wasteland populated by a weird nuclear obsessed cut. Its told in partially in flashbacks and who the characters are becomes clear pretty quick.It was okay but I'm certainly not calling it classic. Kind of a surrealist mad max with a few samurais, a few decent scenes of blood and violence but nothing too extreme. Its got nice visuals but its a little slow, and little light on story.When people who just want to see the next Nicolas Cage action flick get a strange, somewhat slow paced arty mashup of genres I don't know, I think there may be some disappointed viewers when this gets a wide release. There is some weird just for weird sake type stuff in the film, like scene where everyone is clapping or snapping in unison when Bill Mosley arrives, it just goes on a little too long. Same with the shot of the gumball machine, those scenes were kind of pointless and should have been edited down.But I didn't hate this. It looks cool. The actress who plays Bernice is lovely. The mannequins are trippy. I like the scenes where everyone is wearing masks. I'll watch it again. 7/10.

The hell is wrong with you people? Are you that jaded or close minded that you can't have an imagination, think for yourself, or that you need everything spoon fed to you?This movie is balls to the walls amazing, and one hell of a mystical trip from start to finish.
Everyone in this looked like they were reading their lines for the first time...just a confusing mess..

reviews.review_title: The script was written by a stoned cowboy dreaming of Japan, and then throwing mad max in the mix!!
reviews.content: What on God's green earth was Nic cage thinking when he read the script and signed the movie? Who in their right mind would approve such a movie to be made?I couldn't bear the stupidity for more than 28 minutes in my first sitting. It is probably the most ridiculous movie I've watched in my entire life and I finished it in 3 sittings to give it a fair review. It's bad, just too bad.

All i can say that one thing was nice, the little Japanese boy. Beside that its horrible! I cant even say how bad it is. I feel sick!! The acting is below 0. So Law budget. The blood sprays out like ketchup. Sorry that Japan was shown this way! Japan is much more that that. Nicolas Cage PLZ STOP. Retire and take rest.

I felt like someone is messing up my brain! I think worst movie of 2021. The acting was so fake, the story was not connected, lots of mental sickness. I donno what to say more than that in order to sound polite.

Unfortunately, this was kind of bad. I felt the movie was all over the place in terms of what was going on and with all the tangents and scenes not really going anywhere. Nicolas Cage is surprisingly bland for most of it, with maybe one or two exceptions. It didn't feel like there were much stakes to it and I was pretty bored for most of it, which is a shame as the premise is pretty cool, but it didn't deliver much.To give some credit, the set design and aesthetics aren't too bad, as well as the costumes and violence (with little there is). The main villain guy didn't do much for me and I just didn't care at all for the characters. Maybe there were more scenes that were originally there that didn't make the cut? It seemed structurally messy and the weird stuff fell flat for me. This was not worth the journey at all by the end of it.3/10.

reviews.review_title: What the heck did I just watch?
reviews.content: Considering Hollywood is so communist and supports China so vehemently I am shocked to find this is based on Japanese theatre culture.The opening scene is the whole movie. The evil round eyes, Capitalist Pig Americans, take and control the Honest citizens. The real American devil in a fast car that would bust their left nut for immoral values. By the end of the movie I was asking, What the *** did I just watch? What in the *** did I just watch? I can only wonder if this was Frankenstein (Death Race) meets Mad Max meets Kill Bill in A Fist Full of Dollars. There are many scenes that capture the best Mad Max and Karate films over the decades that do not fit in with the rest of the movie. Then there are a number of scenes that fit the Mad Max type movies in the outland. There seems to be one common thread through the whole movie and that is the writer and director was on drugs while making the movie. This is more typical of the 60's drug induced movies than any of the ones mentioned above.This begs the question why did Nicolas Cage make the movie? This too is one of his strangest movies. It keeps switching back and forth from the Nicolas Cage persona we all enjoy and a poorly done psychotic Mad Max. Hollywood has flipped its lid and is putting out some of the worst trash in decades, but for Nicolas Cage to get caught up in this, he had to have owed someone big time for making this garbage.

This is what you get when you take a ton of traditional Japanese outfits, blood splattered Samurai sword fights, some leftover spaghetti Westerns, unwanted props and sets from Mad Max, then increase the colour contrast for the film stock, and finally add a dash of Nicholas Cage.Having been accustomed to Cage's acting, I was pleasantly surprised to see him do well in a leading role where he has less than the usual amount of dialogue.If you want to get extra trippy in an artsy outing, without actually getting high on alcohol, drugs, etc., this is the Super Weird Movie to watch.
Maybe it me.. Or maybe there a point in the universe with an eye for this and will consider this as artBut not me not any human who left the theaterWast of time and money and I think even health.

Nicholas Cage has a reputation for doing some weird films. This one is no exception. It was too odd for me, even though I like some good escapism in a film, but it did have a visual style that should be applauded.If you can handle the weirdness and like cartoonish over-the-top acting then you might like this. Unfortunately, I thought it was boring.

Strange post-apocalyptic that makes you wonder what is going on, so weird? Is this from a manga? What are the cowboy hats gun, weird musical dance & outfit all about? Surely for prisoners of the strange-land that you can't escape...

"The Wildest Movie I've Ever Made" is quite possibly the worst movie the director had ever made. Three stars for the creative visual absurdity of a movie best described as Alice in Wonderland on LSD. Sword fighting fill added to my displeasure.

Sorry, nothing good about this one.I thought the craziness would work to the films advantage but we're not given any context and the acting is atrocious. Similar stories have been done before, this film just fails where they succeeded.

Reading the mixed reviews on here I would say give it a chance you MAY like it but I definitely did not. I won't be watching this one again................................. I should have save my self the times and not watched it.

reviews.review_title: east-meets-west in this trippy art film
reviews.content: As others have pointed out, this movie is pretty trippy. It's tough to describle. It was like a weird mixture of the Walking Dead, Waterworld, Army of the Dead and Army of Darkness... without necessarily having zombies... It does indeed play out like a live action anime. It's not your mainstream action flick. It definitely has an art-film vibe to it. At first, the far-east-far-west mixture was a bit too 'randomly odd,' but it ends up working pretty well in creating this very surreal dream land/limbo setting. If you're not a fan of art house, foreign or other niche film genres, you probably won't like this. I was expecting a pretty typical B Cage movie with this, but was pleasantly surprised. The story is pretty interesting, and the world building is very well done. I think for me the setting was the best part of the film. It somehow doesn't feel quite 'complete', but due to the whole strangeness of it I'm not sure what they could do to round it off a bit more. I would recommend this movie if you like movies on the weirder side, and especially if you like Cage and comic-book like fantasy worlds in general. I'd categorize it more on the fantasy side than scifi, personally. Could have been better, could have definitely been worse. 6/10 overall. 8/10 with some herb.
One weird ass movie. But I enjoyed it. A good one time watch.
Please don't watch this movie. Go watch news or something it's better.
Just bad bad film would not recommend to my worst enemy.

It feels like somebody had an idea of what could have been a sick movie then absolutely went with a rough draft outline without any further writing 😂...this plot was drawn on a napkin and never taken past that.

Yes Nicolas Cage is crazy over the top, yes there are moments with some stunning visuals, but the story felt like a pointless retread of better films. It's overly long and ultimately I found it quite boring. I was very disappointed because I had actually been looking forward to this Sundance premiere.

reviews.review_title: Typically, love the Cage crazies but....
reviews.content: Fell asleep twice trying to get thru this one...I love movies like Mandy but this one is no cult classic. Epic fail. Misleading trailer which makes you think it could have a chance to be entertaining.You can easily pass over this one. Nothing to see here. Mosley and Cage are almost always awesome but man..didn't save Prisoners of the Ghostland.
Waste of time movie.. waste of talent.. no story lineup..👎

reviews.review_title: Drugs are bad kids, don't partake, cos it's a really bad excuse to make a terrible movie.
reviews.content:
An utter mess of a film, nothing makes any sense,
And i mean litteraly nothing.I think who ever wrote this travesty is going for a meta time line thing, but even if you could bare to watch this again, i doubt your health would benefit from it, because to even come close to making sense of this you have to be stoned off your tits and then off your nipples.From what my confused brain has worked out, nic cage is some rando robber 'framed for murder' and then kept in an undisclosed location / jail / prison, till the 'gouvernor' ( no not arnold) decides he's of some use and then gets him out of prison years later, but this is in no way made clear, but with how events happen it's a fair assumption.These bits are fine, but the rest is some seriously trippy crappy things going on through out, 2 towns that make zero sense and their place in the world is never explained, one is a mad max thunderdome meets shanty town and the other is a wierd mix of dark gritty wannabe samurai town and a red light district, with a hint of the wild west cos why not and it's like trying to emulate many things from these genres but just throws them in to all scenes to be artistic and symbolic ? But it's a convoluted mess.For those who only speak english i would advise looking for subtitles as there is a lot of non english speaking, you could get the gist but it's a slog cos there is long scenes with no english.If you here just for nic then you can probs skip any scene he isn't in and still get some enjoyment but as a whole this film is utter garbage and no amount of 'justification' or genre bending mumbo jumbo is holding water for me.It's terrible AVOID.

reviews.review_title: You don't need to watch this.
reviews.content: Just didn't grab my attention. A lot of different elements... some of them cool... A lot more of them silly. Ultimately, the films boring and nonsensical and I couldn't sit through it.Nicholas cage is doing his usual mad man act, only one thing stood out to me in terms of his performance, and it was when he soooooo obviously used a body double. Lmao! It was hilarious, only because they show the top half of his body so clearly for like 5 whole seconds, then, right after that, we see this buff ripped body that's meant to be his but with all the hair on his chest missing, good pecs, built legs and rippling abs, this had me laughing my head off... Hollywood man, never change.Visually (In terms of direction) it was well done, a couple of off moments here and there, but overall decent. ALSO, a huge shout out to the prop master and set designer because some of those visuals were just super interesting to me... Just a shame they weren't in a better written film.I stopped at the 50-minute mark, just couldn't take it anymore, any movie I can't finish is an instant 1 unfortunately. With all that said, I genuinely hope all the people that worked on this movie do well within the industry... except the writer lol lord knows what drivel they'll create next. Although, in Hollywood you tend to fail up, so... guess I'll be seeing his work again soon lmao.
I like to check out all Nicks movies as you can find some real gems, but this one couldn't be saved by him. It really sucks, but I don't blame Nick. I couldn't get past 15 minutes and shut it off.

A very strange movie, like most of Cage's last movies, and that's what makes it different, its strange choices, bizarre quirks that we love... I liked it dark and colorful, dystopian, with doses of dark humor, little fun, boring for some long fights, but it has oriental co-production, inevitable, I love these eccentric works, fan of Cage and his preferences with different nuances...
So bad I couldn't finish it. I've seen better B movies in the nineties.
If you can get through the 1st 20 minutes good luck.

This movie is like a dream and it's beatiful. It make perfect sense where it must and makes no sense where it shouldn't, and it makes it easy for you to get lose your grip on whether it should or shouldn't.

What was this dude... 20 minutes in and i was like "WTH why am i watching this?" Weird movie, characters acting very strange, dancing together for no reason and looking like all of them had mental disorders.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies, EVER
reviews.content: I have to say that this is one of the worst movies that I've ever seen in Nicolas Cages' lifetime (and I can say that since I am a few years older than him), and I'm including ALL movies produced since he was born, not just his. Such a disappointment. I've been a Cage fan since "Valley Girl." I like his on-screen quirkiness, understand his personal financial woes, consider him entertaining, etc....but this movie is just plain BAD. Do not waste your time on it. If you are a N. C. fan who is determined to watch regardless, it'd be better if you closed your eyes and covered your ears! Let's hope that there are better offerings which include N. C. in 2022.
I loved Mandy, but I think this movie is unbearably dumb. Female lead is also French-Chinese, but the movie takes place in Japan, so it feels off & racist from the beginning.
This is so bad..the set is cool with the samurai and cowboy theme...BUT the story and acting sucks to bad. If you have 1hr 42 minutes to waste watch it, otherwise I wish I could get mine back.

What was the plot of this movie? The scenes were choppily edited together without any flow; in one scene, Nicolas Cage passes out, and 1 second later, he's awake. I couldn't understand anything. Also, why did the Japanese swordsman suddenly betray him? None of this makes any sense.Also, what is Nicolas Cage even doing in Japan in the 1st place?Not recommended. If I could give this movie a zero, I would.

Reading other reviews,
i like the opposites as like a medal.I wish the sound track had been less clinical in sounding , and more unique special.Also, camera and edit was not stylistic for it want to be western mix with samurai.

This movie is super weird but not in an good way.Things happen on the screen but my brain just can follow it.This movie makes no sense at all what so ever.I really tried but had to turn if off after 20 or 30 minutes.Completely unwatchable.Don't say I didn't warn you!

Remember the days before China was really big, and cheap knock-offs of every product were made in Japan? Well... this movie is a cheap knock-off of every post-apocalyptic movie ever done, with a bit more of "Mad Max" in the mix. It also shows a strange indecision between assuming the identity of a musical (or even an Opera) and the identity of an empty headed 80's movie primed for Meat Loaf-era heavy metal braindead headbangers.Definitely a miss. The only cheerful moment in the movie is that Nicholas Cage's character gets to have one of his balls blown-off by a bomb.

Well at least I have found the worst Nicholas Cage movie to date. I was really hoping it wouldn't be as bad as the review score it had. It was actually worse!Unlikeable characters, terrible voices, it was fine when there were sub titles during the Japanese dialogue, but near the end of the film there were some pointless secondary characters shouting, garbled words...who the heck knows what - clearly all the other fill in actors knew what was said as they were happily cheering. Gosh, it was just all so bad. Do yourself a favour - and go and catch a sun tan outside instead. You will achieve more and not waste your life on this boring drivvle.Avoid - worst movie I've forced myself to sit through in the past few years!

Honestly I can't help but wonder how much much Nicholas cage Wass offered to star in this travesty of a movie. The movie was directionless, confusing, and just now worth watching. I stopped caring for it after 20mins and had to keep skipping it till the end.
WTF???????? What poison was this I saw? Wasting time..

I like nic cage and most of the films hes done in recent years, but this film was just to wierd for me, its like it was trying so hard to be unique and different, it was to surreal, and i just couldnt make sense of it.

Take Fellini, Pasolini, Kurosawa, Ken Russel, Jodorowsky, add a bit of Tarantino, stir it up and hope for the best. Perhaps if the script was written by Murakami one may end up with something. As it is they ended up with a hotchpotch of pretentious, pseudo avant-garde, postmodernist nonsense.
It would have been better if it was comedy. The entire movie is pointless, the plot, the visual and even the characters.
You can make bad movies. I don't care. You can make bad movies that a unique visual look. Good on you. But you still need your movie to have a story that makes some kind of sense.
Why You should watch this? I don't have any reason. At least I haven't seen any movie like this before.

reviews.review_title: I'm seeing a trend lately of loads of people just crapping on movies just because!!!

reviews.review_title: Something was not quite as it should be
reviews.content: Not completely Sion Sono's fault because he didn't write this 'Kabuki' horror story. I adored its Neo-Western concept and surrealist set pieces but something wasn't quite as it should be. Nic Cage & Boutella made an absurd pair audience should cheer.

Not an ardent fan of Japanese sci-fi, but can still appreciate it. Three fourths into the movie and were the reel to break, I wouldn't be too upset. IMO, Cage bears most of the load. Were he not in it, I would have passed on this movie.

I enjoyed this movie. A couple of things stopped me from giving it a 10 though - the sets seemed very cheap, and the crowd seemed a bit awkard while Nic was walking around. They didn't really seem into it which pulled me out of the story.This is supposed to be a crazy adventure, but i feel like they didn't add enough crazy to the receipe. They could have amped it up a bit more, and except for two scenes (a ball explosion and a neck slice) it didn't have nearly enough gore for me.In summary - I really liked this movie, the cast, acting, writing wasn't too bad, direction etc; but it lost 1 point for not enough gore, 1 point for the cheap sets and unconvincing crowds, and 1 point for a lack of crazy.If you're a fan of Nic's other recent work, I'm sure you'll enjoy this, you might just need a couple of drinks to help you ignore the imperfections.

reviews.review_title: Everything was a fingersign to the viewer. Good film sets.
reviews.content: There are some great actors in this film, but every direction they had was terrible.A film has to be watchable in some degree, which means real people need real self-preservation, real reactions. The start was a slow motion, confused mess. At other times, people started singing all together randomly (taking the power of the actors away, and sense of reality). Samurai had sympathy faces much of the time instead of flat ruthless faces. Sword fights among samurai were for length & show (banging swords on swords in panic), instead of deliberate. People meeting each other was like contrived funeral proceedings each time.

It just one nonsensical scene after another.The movie is supposed to be an action horror sci-fi, expect there almost no action and nothing was scary. What little action there was, was badly choreographed. A 57 old Cage is slow and cumbersome thru the fight scene.Don't waste your time and money with this movie.

Visuals are peculiar, even mesmerizing at times - especially costumes. But that's where the amusing part ends, and it's not even that good. The rest is a meaningless journey through pointless set of nonsensical dialogues that don't bring anything to the story - not uncovering any plot, not explaining any lore, not even being mysterious or bizarre; it's just a set of vaguely relevant phrases. The acting by the background cast is alright - they're mostly standing still or performing some unexpected dancing, which looks aligned with the garbage aesthetics around them. But the main cast is just not doing anything apart from perhaps goofing around.It could've at least been properly bloody or cryptic or lively or grotesque or something definite, but alas it's none of those.

That's not to say it was a great piece of art, but I did thoroughly enjoy watching this movie. Maybe I'm biased, since I'm a sucker for samurai movies, westerns, and anything Cage is in, but for what it is, I think it's worth a watch. The visuals and set designs are gorgeous, and while most of the performances aren't anything to cry home about, Cage has his moments as he always does. It's not "the wildest movie he's has been in," as Cage himself puts it, but it's fun enough that I don't mind. And for what it's worth, it is fairly wild.

Some reviewers are pretending it's creative art and you need to be open minded to appreciate this... there were two shots that had no meaning but were visually impressive. The entire film is absurd, but not in a good way, not with any merit at all. The acting is sooo bad, the characters are sooo ridiculous. To me, it was just annoying. This is not a movie I would typically ever watch but my aunt rented it from Redbox and my grandparents wanted to give it a chance. I was ready to turn it off within the first 10 minutes but ended up watching the whole thing with them. It never got any better. I was glad when it was over. Adding this to the list of worst movies I've ever seen. It's listed as "action" , "syfy" , and "thriller". There's some action but it's definitely not a thriller. The only syfy aspect was the ridiculous unexplained costumes and zombie like creatures. Overall, this movie had no substance. I honestly don't get the critics here. Did you watched the same trailer as I did? Because no reasonable person would see that and expect a movie with a good plot.This is a bizarre, absurd, weird, bloody movie. Exactly as advertised. If anything, it fell short of how bizarre it could have been.It is not great, not even at it's own game, but it's certainly not as bad as critics say.

"Dont mess my white shoes up"Right now, all I can say is that, I'm struggling to put my thoughts into words over here. Can't remember the last time, I have witnessed such absurd yet ruminative execution. From testicles bursting to slitted throats, from people in weird dresses doing some weird stuff to sudden sightings of supernatural beings; trust me, you will be getting the full course of lunacy in there.However, at the same time, what you also get is a tangible story that allegorically speaks of Redemption, Retribution and Liberty. With the help of some stunning set designs and an outstanding Score; Prisoners of the Ghostland achieves a whole new tier of cinema. A world that is comprised of the dystopian rendition of our civilization as well as a ton of real-life elements derived directly from the community we currently inhabit.Now, coming to Performances, Nicholas Cage steals the limelight, once again. People may poke fun at him, make jokes about his script selections, but no one in their right mind would deny his dedication and talent. A film like Pig is nothing but a testimony to my argument! Barring Cage, Sofia Boutella as Bernice and Bill Moseley as the Governor are two other important additions as well. If only the character of Yasujiro had a nicer portrayal. Real shame!So to summarise, if you ask me, I had a good enough time, I was able to acknowledge the irregularities; even though I do realize that's not gonna be the case for everyone. It will depend upon your openness to creativity and the very craft of experimental filmmaking. If you are ever in a mood for some offbeat, quirky action; make sure to tune in. I assure you, it would be worth your while.

reviews.review_title: Visually Stunning, Wild, but Flawed Movie
reviews.content: This was a movie that I planned on seeing at the theater, but I couldn't make the times work. When I saw that it came to Shudder, I then decided to watch it there. I did hear some mixed reviews on it, so I was curious how this would be. It worked out as an interesting double feature on Journey with a Cinephile: A Horror Movie Podcast. The synopsis is a notorious criminal must break an evil curse in order to rescue an abducted girl who has mysteriously disappeared.For this movie, most of it is taking place in Samurai Town. There is also another name for it, but I didn't write it down. It is run by the Governor (Bill Moseley). We get to see a scene of Hero (Nicolas Cage) along with his partner Psycho (Nick Cassavetes) as they rob a bank. There is this child that is offering gumballs and Psycho aims his gun at this boy. Hero does what he can to prevent this.Coupling with this we have Bernice (Sofia Boutella) trying to flee the town. She is being aided by geishas and her friend Susie (Yuzuka Nakaya). In order to get out, they need to ensure that the guards are taken care of. They don't seem to get far though as something happens to them.That is when the Governor calls Hero before him. He is fitted into a leather suit that has bombs attached to the arms, neck and genitals. These bombs will go off he tries to strike a woman, if he gets fresh with one or he tries to remove the suit. He has five days to get Bernice and bring her back to the Governor, or he will die.This begins the journey into what is dubbed the ghostland. We see monstrous man that was killed. It appears he was a notorious criminal and now he is holding everyone prisoner there. He has an army of mindless soldiers and even what looks to be samurais. Hero will do whatever he can to save Bernice and break this curse before it is too late. The real question though, who is the real villain here?Where I want to start then for me actually breaking down the movie is that I did see part of the trailer for this when Jaime and I went to the Gateway Film Center. This movie is visually stunning and I knew that from what I saw. It is quite interesting as well as there is a lot of allegory and referencing that we are also getting here. The imaginary is well done by director Sion Sono as well. I was braced coming in that this was going to wild and it doesn't disappoint there. Not necessarily in the way that I was expecting though.The first thing that I should get into is that this movie is paying homage to westerns and the basis for those movies, the samurai tale. We are combining them in an interesting way. I'm not overly versed in westerns and I have not seen much in the way of the samurai films either. I do know that westerns adopted the nameless hero from this sub-genre and from Japan. It is a direct reference here that Cage's character is named Hero. Much like you'd get in westerns, he's a flawed character and this is a redemption tale for him. We are also getting a lot of traditional ideas mixed with more modern ones. The Governor is white. He is ruling this town as a capitalist. I can see that in westerns since the richest guy usually did run things. Yasujiro (Tak Sakaguchi) is a samurai forced to be his bodyguard due to Susie or at least that is what she believes. Plus we have Sheriff Takato (Takato Yonemoto) and Deputy Shin (Shin Shimizu) who provide the Governor almost an army of cowboys. The other things that struck me here were the amount of geishas while it still feeling like a western town. It is an interesting blend with the style of architecture of Japan. I found this to be visually interesting.There is also some intriguing social commentary here. I've already alluded to this movie speaking out about capitalism. Hero and Psycho are poor so they rob a bank. The Governor is controlling this town with money. He is a villain from the beginning. I like that this movie is trying to blur the lines of good and bad. Hero killed people, but he does what is right. The Governor and Psycho are worse. We are never getting that they're good, but I would say that the Governor does come off neutral in the start. The movie is able to be subtle with this to the point where you can ignore it if you'd like.The other commentary is the idea of nuclear power. It would appear this movie is speaking out against it along with the use of weapons. There was a power plant that melted down and how the waste was being stored caused problems. This again goes back to capitalism as well. I'm assuming this is in part to what happened to the nuclear plant quite a few years ago that melted down as well as the bombings from World War II. The demon that is holding everyone prisoner in the ghostland was affected by the toxic waste causing him to become what he has. This has vibes of The Toxic Avenger with this idea as well.I believe with that I've broken down the story enough. Where I should go would be how this is all conveyed. We have some beautiful shots here so I'll give credit to Sono along with the director of photography, Sôhei Tanikawa. Together they are able to convey some things with showing us. There is a dream like feel to this and almost like a surreal take as well. There are many times I wasn't sure what was real and what wasn't. Going along with this would be the effects. We don't get a lot here which surprised me. What we do looked to be practical for the most part from what I can remember. The blood we do get looked good. This movie does get wild as it gets to its climax for sure. Aside from that, I'd say the soundtrack fit for what was needed. We get the atmosphere of being in a Japanese town while also mixing in some tracks that worked for the scenes.Then the last thing will be the acting. Nicolas Cage is an interesting actor to me. I think he is good, but he needs the right director. I think that for the most part Sono was able to rein him in. He does over act a bit out there that didn't work for me. Boutella is an actress I'm not overly impressed with. I thought she was okay here. Cassavetes was good as Psycho. He fit that role. I love how over the top Moseley plays his role. He seems like a villain from the beginning. Sakaguchi was solid along with Young Dais and Nakaya. I think the supporting cast was good for what was needed.In conclusion here, I was a bit let down by this movie if I'm going to be honest. I tried to temper my expectations, but it is hard when most things I've seen from Sono I have liked. That's not to say I hated this, because that's not the case. I enjoyed the references to westerns and samurai films, even though I'm not as versed in them as I should be. I thought that Cage over acted and I'm not high on Boutella, but the rest of the cast worked for me. The cinematography for this movie is amazing. I thought that the soundtrack fit for what was needed as well. The commentary under what we are seeing also worked for me. I'd say that this is still an above average movie despite my issues.

Where do I start with this movie, basically it's live action anime, in my opinion, colorful, weird, wacky and nightmarish in some scenes, I wish the story had maybe be a little more complicated, instead of Escape from New York goes to hell, featuring every genre of film thrown together, Nic Cage get to be what else Nic Cage, playing a rogue who get an offer he can't refuse and we follow with him thru this rabbit hole of weirdness, I had to view this film twice to fully understand what I watched the first time , before I gave my opinion on this movie, overall it seemed to me that filmmaker wanted to make an action film art house style, whether it's good or bad, I'll leave that as questionable, I will leave with saying that this was Kabuki theater with Nic Cage.

Nicolas Cage has had an interesting career. Academy Award winner, Golden Globe award winner, box office draw. Then a divorce and tax issues took their toll financially. A few films that didn't do the same box office business previous films resulted in him taking on nearly any project that came his way. Among those were some of the best performances of his career (JOE and MANDY among them). But like a number of actors who were strong in the late 80s through 90s the studios were tossing him less stellar roles. Which is sad.PRIOSNERS OF THE GHOSTLAND is not likely to raise Cage's profile. While a solid film it's a bit too strange for most viewers. Cage does a great job here but that's not enough to save the film from the oddness that is on screen.The film takes place in a future Japan ravaged by nuclear waste. Cage plays Hero, a big time bank robber who hits a bank with partner Psycho (Nick Cassavetes). In the course of the robbery a number of people are killed including a small child. Hero is captured and tossed into the dankest cell they can find in a place called Samurai Town.One day Hero is removed from his cell and brought out to meet the Governor (Bill Mosely), the ruler of Samurai Town. Given a new leather suit to wear he puts it on willingly and is then told why he's been summoned. One of the Governor's "granddaughters" has left the town and entered the Ghostland. In return for rescuing his "granddaughter" the Governor agrees to let Hero free.To insure that he doesn't run off, the new outfit he is wearing comes with preventive measures. Explosive devices are embedded in the outfit, two near his private parts, one on each are and two on his neck. Should he get excited and attempt to molest the girl the lower bombs explode. If he attempts to strike her the ones in his arms. And if he should fail to return her in 3 days all of them explode at once.Hero sets out to his task only to wreck the car he was in when faced with a mirage. Or was it? In any event he is rescued by the Ratman, a strange person who comes from deep inside Ghostland. He takes him to the main city, if you can call it that, and there Hero learns that no one escapes from Ghostland. He sees an odd assortment of people there from clock worshipping cult to scavengers of the land.Hero gets a lead on Bernice (Sofia Boutella), the "granddaughter" he was searching for. He rescues her and tries to leave only to be stopped. In a world where the strange is normal, where ghosts might be real and where the followers of a clock cult may hold the answer, Hero must find a way to escape Ghostland or face his own death.What sounds like a pretty straightforward film is far from it. The story her feels like a mashup of so many films we've already seen, in particular the MAD MAX movies. Toss in a western or two as well as some surreal Japanese fantasy films and you get the picture. The problem is that we jump back and forth from one to the other and zig zag back and forth in time and space so much that it's easy to get lost. Add to that the film is half in Japanese requiring subtitles and it makes it that much more difficult.Visually the movie is stunning, the Ghostland the least so as it feels like any other post-apocalyptic world we've seen countless times over. Dirt everywhere, mechanical backdrops and more. The sequences in Samurai Town are exquisite though with bright colors and fabrics as well as some eerie walls of faces that work well. The cinematography of the entire film is crisp and clean and well thought out. The best parts of this film are these.Cage does a fine job here given what he has but it is Bill Mosely who stands out among the actors. A slight touch of southern gentleman, prognosticating politician, slick con man and lecherous old man all come together in the character of the Governor and that's in no small part to his performance. Mosely has always been relegated to smaller roles or lead parts in some of the goriest films made. This shows he has deserved better.On the whole this movie looks spectacular but as far as an entertaining film to watch repeatedly it falls far short of that goal. Still, if you can't find anything better this week you might want to give it a watch.

reviews.review_title: Bonkers style mish mash, just for the hell of it
reviews.content: The later day career trajectory of Nick Cage sees him wrapped up in an arms race, with directors competing to see who can make him scream his way through the most insane situations. Personally, I'm all for it. However, from the looks of it, this particular blend of art house sensibilities and B-movie aesthetics seems to be rubbing people the wrong way.The core premise is a simplistic hero/villain/damsel in distress narrative that strings you along, but isn't winning any points for complexity. What sets the film apart is it's gonzo delivery. Jumping genres from Western, to Samurai, to post apocalyptic, approaching everything with a surrealism that favours the absurd over traditional logic. Action fans will inevitably complain that "nothing makes sense" and the art crowd will probably deem the violent fight sequences too low-brow. But if you find yourself somewhere in between, there's much to admire. The set design is glorious, juxtaposing Mad Max-esque junkyard future aesthetics with a lavish geisha brothel. The soundtrack is suitably epic, mixing Morricone and 80s synth. The patented Cage Rage may be somewhat underused, but it did provide him an excellent opportunity to yell "TESTICLE!" which will undoubtedly end up in the next freak out compilation.

Nicolas cage Is OK, the design and costumes are actuallq quite good but the director is a mess it is imposible to uderstand the the red thred trough this storry, and it is also from time to Time childich a mess. Tarantino whanabe.

For those who keep hoping Nicholas Cage is going to turn into some mythological creature like you imagined him in other films, stop it. He's an actor. He has a style. He sees a script and does what he wants each time. It doesn't always hit for some people but that's Cage. He doesn't deserve the extreme 1 star hit jobs.This film reminds me of the 'tongue in cheek' Cage. 'Tough guy but laughs at the situation around him' Cage. The sets are purposely designed to be kitschy like a horror comic. The references to Mad Max (Thunderdome not Road Warrior) is also on purpose.It's one of my favorite kinds of film. It's a mish mash of styles (western, apocalyptic, Crime-revenge, Japanese kabuki, etc) and l take it for what it is. Not sure I'd give it any esteemed awards but maybe some cult festivals, horror, fantasy fest medals.And anyone who gave this a 1 star has not seen enough films to know what a 1 star really means. All films deserve at least four stars for basically having a story, music, editing, acting that is passable. Then you add a star for each element that excelled for you.For me one star for visuals. Exciting and colorful. One more star for fun, cheesy romp in the always interesting comic book style. One more star for Cage being Cage. And one more star for his supporting cast for playing along to this insanity that elevates it to cult status.

Based off of this and the Five Nights At Freddie's ripoff Nicolas Cage did, it would seem he may be paid per word of dialogue, and the less pay, the less effort. If you like post nuclear apocalypse, samurai, body horror, western, comedies, then you'll probably like it too.Nick cage, is the most fun to watch when he's making these weird B movies.People need to stop taking everything so seriously.

reviews.review_title: Could be good... if you are on LSD? And even..maybe not.
reviews.content: Honestly i wasn't expecting that much from this movie. The premise made it sound a bit like some Escape from New York/LA and with Nic Cage starring, could had been fun. I know his track record of Direct to Video ain't stellar, but the dude can be charismatic and funny at times even if the movie is subpar.Sadly this movie is not only the worst movie i saw in 2022 so far, but also the worst movie i watched from Nic Cage. A Score to Settle had a good premise, but end up being a boring drag fest, yet at least the story made some sense. It bored me, but not made me roll my eyes thinking "wtf am i watching".The problem with Prisonners of the Ghostland is not the direction, music, or even the acting (wich without being amazing, is not bad either). Its the story. It makes no sense !This is basically a simple premise you seen many times, in the afformentioned "Escape from" with Kurt Russel, only here, maybe it was a matter of budget, or filming location rights, but basically this is like a 20-25 minute short that they drag for an hour and 40 minutes. There is pretty much 2 locations in the whole movie.Scenes drag and drag with a bunch of nonsense, weird characters, some "japanese stuff" that just make you wonder what it is supose to be, only feeling like padding. Maybe if i was high on LSD i would had fun with the nonsense, but even tipsy on beer i did not one bit. So if you watch Jeremy Jahn, this is NOT a "good time if you're drunk. Not even a "won't remember it in T-minus 1 day". But clearly his worst rating...I am somebody who is easily please with movies. I can apreciate a dumb movie, even more when im on beer. I had so much fun with Prince of the Sun with Cynthia Rothrock, this movie was so dumb but funny dumb. I watch Batman and Robin from time to time and just laugh with it.Sometimes i just watch direct to video cheap action movies cause among them there is some hidden gems. Often i finish them and i just think "meh...guess it passed time". What i mean is they not amazing, won't ever watch them again, but they were alright to watch once most of the time. Even the worst ones, i would usually give them a 4. They are clearly subpar, often boring, but rarely completely atrocious.Prisonners of the Ghost Land only had me look at the remaining time about a dozen if not more times, i kept rolling my eyes thinking "wtf am i watching". This movie make Jiu Jitsu (another Nic Cage DTV) looks like a Masterpiece. At least there is some action and the story make some sense.I think this may be the first 2 stars i ever give, don't quote me on it, but even some of the worst movies there is, i usually give them 3 or 4, as i can apreciate a tiny bits of them. Here i give 2 stars because the VERY few sword action scenes there was were decent. I mean they were nicely filmed and competent overall. But there is so few of them and they matter so few in the story, not making you engage at all, that i can't give them more than 2 stars.Even with what i said above, that the direction, music, acting, camera work etc, was all fine, you would think it would deserve more than 2. But NO, the issue is the story being so bad and dragging and dragging, making you go between "what is going on" and "im sooo bore, does it end soon" , i can't give it the same rating i would give a generic boring action direct to video.Alright, i know im dragging this review , but if you think THIS is dragging, oh boy do not watch this movie :PAll i wanted was a cool action movie with Nic Cage having to go into "Mad Max territories" to rescue someone important. :/

reviews.review_title: A strange left turn, sustained for 100 minutes
reviews.content: While not truly knowing what to expect, I'd be lying if I said I didn't enter this film with certain expectations. I've seen several of filmmaker Sion Sono's movies and enjoyed them (I especially loved 'Love exposure' and 'Why don't you play in hell?'). This comes in the midst of a strong period in recent years in Nicolas Cage's career, including 'Mandy,' 'Colour out of space,' 'Willy's Wonderland,' and 'Pig.' And while I'm less familiar with Sofia Boutella, any time I have seen her I've been impressed (Gaspar Noé's 'Climax,' 2017 action-thriller 'Atomic blonde'). While not all equal, Sono's pictures commonly claim wild, unorthodox flavors of over the top, playful embellishment, so with Cage on board as such, who better to tackle a tale smashing together the western genre, Japanese culture, facets of horror, and traces of John Carpenter's 'Escape from New York?'As quickly as 'Prisoners of the Ghostland' begins what comes across is that, perhaps encouraged by the opportunity to make his first picture in English, Sono seized the chance to be as absolutely Extra as he possibly could be. Everything here seems cranked up to 11 and self-indulgent - the production design and art direction, stunts and effects, scene writing and direction, characters, narrative, plot development. Even at that, in many ways this still feels like it fits neatly within the filmmaker's oeuvre; if the feature were a wholly Japanese production, I don't think anyone would have batted an eye at all the overcooked abstruseness - a lot of people wouldn't get it, but 'Prisoners' would be passed off as Sono being Sono, and left at that. With the greater visibility that came with the casting and nature of this production, however, scrutiny has been heightened, as though folks suddenly feel license to be critical in ways they wouldn't otherwise.Mind you, this is definitely not to say that this feature is or should be free from critical eyes. In an off-kilter way I'm reminded of Sono's directorial debut, 2001's 'Suicide Club': for much of its length it built a strong, cohesive narrative that was distinctly building toward something, but it reached a point where the writing took a left turn or two (or three) and coherence fell away a bit. While 'Prisoners' can claim a complete and obliquely compelling story, Aaron Hendry and Reza Sixo Safai's screenplay, and Sono's realization of it, comes across as that same bizarre narrative turn, writ large and sustained over the entirety of these 100 minutes. I admire the unswerving daring to create a feature of such extreme, disjointed, complicated, and muddied storytelling, embracing every weird impulse and flourish. I would have admired the film itself far more if the excess and jazzed up frills were reined in even just a tad. As it is, this is kind of all over the place, and seems like it's barely holding itself together.I can honestly say that I do like 'Prisoners of the Ghostland.' I think it's made very well in all ways, such as it is, and though the cast is guided into chewing scenery - well, that fits the slant of the production, doesn't it? This is outrageous and totally overdone across the board, but only by intention. I just wish the slightest measure of self-restraint had been employed at any point, because in writing and in execution the movie takes the longest, strangest, most winding, least direct road to telling its story. This simply didn't need to be as much as it is. I don't even know who I would recommend this to except for folks who already know and are enamored with Sono's style, or similarly odd fare, and even then it will be hard-pressed to find appeal with all. I commend everyone involved for the work they put into it, and I believe 'Prisoners of the Ghostland' turned out better than not, but I also can't begrudge anyone for disliking a title that goes out of its way to be fancifully and outlandish.
Visually, Prisoners is pretty cool. But it's bizarro hodge-podge otherwise. Cage is out to find the governor's daughter in a suit with mini bombs over his arms, neck and testicles.

What a piece of nonsensical trash!No directing, no script, no budget, no acting, no sense, no nothing!!!Couldn't stand it. And (imagine!) I am a Nicolas Cage fan!!!!God, what a torture it was to watch the whole thing!

From the first 10 minutes it seems to be trash. Very wasting time movie. Really How ??

Well, this was quite possibly one of if not the worst movie I've ever suffered through. I thought it would be stupid-funny, silly, cheesy-action, but no. You just cringe the entire time it plays out. I honestly can't remember ever seeing acting so badly forced, maybe from a literal B-movie, maybe. It is filled with continuity issues, or at best questions, loads of heavy handed symbolism missing the mark, and the thinest attempt at a plot I've seen in quite some time. The movie has subtitles for the Japanese lines, but none for a number of characters who speak in just mumble-groans, which is by design, but makes you question why even bother as it adds absolutely nothing.Partly produced by the same crew as Mandy and Color Out of Space. You get some of the weird with this one, but absolutely none of the enjoyment.You can start this movie at any random spot, watch for 15 minutes, and probably get the same out of it as having watched it in full. Do yourself a favor - if curiosity is killing the cat, just watch the trailer twice and save yourself the time.

reviews.review_title: Not For Everyone. Probably Not For You, Either.
reviews.content: This movie is, to put it mildly, an experience. If you go in expecting things like fleshed out characters, a cohesive narrative, or even a three-act structure, you will be left frustrated and irritated. Instead of anything resembling a movie, Prisoners of the Ghostland is more of a collection of scenes and moments without any kind of logic or traditional plot applied.There is a concept of a story: Hero, a bank robber, is tasked with rescuing the Governor of Samurai Town's "Granddaughter" from the Ghostland, a cursed place, blasted and scarred by nuclear radiation. Hero is outfitted in a leather suit with explosives that will detonate if he, in any way, goes against his orders. With Hero setting off in a child's bicycle, the adventure begins.As others have said, the plotting and pace are bizarre. Nic Cage spends a good chunk of the first half unconscious, having repeated flashbacks to the failed robbery that led to his imprisonment, and his guilt manifesting in visions of a child who was killed on that fateful day. These flashbacks recur through the entire movie, even well into the climax. Granted, the sight of brightly-colored gumballs flying through the air in slow motion is beautiful, but after the sixth or seventh time can become a bit much.Similar to Cage's previous genre entry Mandy, almost all of the action and chaos is backloaded onto the second half of the story. This is where (in my opinion at least) the movie redeems itself. As a huge fan of Tak Sakaguchi, seeing him face off against Cage is worth the price of admission alone. Even though Sakaguchi does most of the heavy lifting on the action side of things - especially when facing off against a dozen enemy samurai - Cage does a decent job holding his own, especially at his age. As carnage unfolds in all directions, Sion Sono's style comes to the forefront, with gorgeous imagery and bonkers over-the-top violence that the director has become known for.In short, I really, really liked this one. I even pre-ordered the blu ray the moment I left the theater. However, every negative thing you've been told about Prisoners of the Ghostland is accurate. Whether it was due to time or budgetary constraints, it barely feels like a finished movie. There is no flow to the story, characters come and go from the story without reason, and the movie can't even respect its own internal logic.With that said, your enjoyment of this will be directly proportional to how much/little you care about conventional filmmaking, and whether or not you can enjoy an unfinished mess that features nonstop sakura blossoms falling while Nic Cage screams "TESTICLLLLLLE" to a crowd of confused onlookers. In other words: The critics and other reviewers are all correct: This is bad. Really bad. Unbearably and oppressively bad.But it's MY kind of bad.
This movie is really the worst bad movie ever. Bad filming bad story bad characters a lot of unnecessary movement.

Some song writers like John Lennon and Bob Dylan have laughed at attempts to make sense of some of their stranger lyrics. Same principal with "Prisoners of the Ghostland". Those watching it in hopes of the usual filmic ingredients - plot/understandable dialogue/things that make sense - will be quickly disappointed.Some movies should just be experienced and this is one. Like a fever dream come to life, "Prisoners" is a candy-apple, sparkle coated deam/mare come to life. The colors are incredibly deep. Many scenes are nearly delusional. Cage does what he does best - work right on the edge of diving deep into over-acting hack territory and pulls out a performance only he can do - sincerely unhinged, often saying more by just reacting silently than pages of dialogue could do.I like many big, mainstream films. I like heartfelt dramas, some to the point of schmaltz. Comedies. Documentaries. But I'm always looking for something totally off the rails. As long as it's done well, I'm all in."Prisoners of the Ghostland" is a very well done, off-the-rails film.

I wasted a half hour of my life on this, really should have gave up sooner..

Carnie, cyber/stream punk, post apocalyptic meets spaghetti samurai. Don't take this too seriously and enjoy the ride.

I was looking forward to a new scary movie that was full of color and maybe a sub plot, and no super heroes. This was not that movie. It started off with a silly scenario, and continued with dumb actions that Nicholas made to either be ironic or funny. The only creepy scenes were apparently in the trailer, and they weren't that creepy in the movie. I didn't understand what was going on most of the time. I didn't watch to the end, so maybe everything got straightened out. That's the only reason I gave this 4 stars. I'm not sure I will try it again. Very disappointed.

reviews.review_title: I was looking for something more...
reviews.content: I was in the mood for something bonkers with substance. I got the bonkers, but not the substance. I was expecting something akin to Battle Royale or even a toned down Ichi The Killer. Maybe I was foolish to go in with such expectations, or maybe the trailer led me astray. The film did have interesting visuals and sets so Sion Sono does have a good eye for that. But the story was incoherent to me. Parts of it just made no sense.This is a different kind of movie. And that may be what the director was going for. If so he succeeded. But to have this kind of bombast there needs to be a good story. I don't feel that I wasted my time. I just feel that this could have been a better movie with some tweaking.

Spent the first 15 minutes thinking WTF? WTF? WTF am I watching? Then I just gave up. I can't imagine what people must have thought in the cinema watching this movie. Must have been pure torture.Words can't describe this, it's impossible to put up spoilers here, the whole movie is spoiled. As are the 15 minutes I will never get back.Please give Cage a proper movie as he certainly deserves it. I can only imagine he did this to pay some bills.

A bizarre mashup of western samurai and post apocalyptic genres. Good visuals and simple story but overall fell flat and pacing slow. I watched it for Nic Cage of course and he always gives a good performance. The problem is the directing. Many scenes just drag and the weird geisha background and chanting gets annoying. It's just like Escape from New York except here it's Japan. Nic Cage goes into the wasteland to rescue a girl and fights samurai and meets all kinda weird while wearing a suit rigged with explosives that detonate if he doesn't meet deadlines. The movie has a decent budget, nice set pieces, okay fight sequences and you can't go wrong with Nic Cage and Sofia Boutella. But overall it falls flat because of lousy directing. Still it's worth a watch for Nic Cage fans. Fast forwarding can get thru the slow parts.

reviews.review_title: It's 2021! How can we still make movies like this?

The leaders are portrayed by dignified white men, while all East Asians are portrayed as scabby, scavenging savages. The worse of all are how all the Asian women are really not much more than hoars and prositutes. For Pete's sake, it's 2021 you'd think someone from writing, to producing, to directing to the actors would of picked up on this. But clearly not.

Weirdest movie ever. I like Nick Cage but gee wizards he can make some bad movies...leaves me wondering why.... I did laugh when her blew his gonad off though.

I have seen this Movie only for Cage, Considering its a low budget movie its not bad, for me it was watchable, i have seen worst and worst but honestly this is not in that level.Nicolas Cage performance is Great, camera directing was good too, the script was Poor including a strange inconceivable story.I rated 4 stars only for performance of Cage, appreciate the high work of Nicolas rate it.

The title says it all. It was not written by sono.In my opinion they should ask Sono what movie do you want to write, and how much does it cost to make.Anyway, what you get is great ending credits. The best couple of sets of this year.Excellent editing. Colorful almost theatrical performances and some snippets of the man's genius.Not sure Nicholas cage was needed. He does do his usual performance. But you know you are looking at Cage.And that perhaps detracts from the sets and camerawork which is again excellent.Bundled with some of the best editing skills you get a movie with a pretty weak story but told in such a way that the time moves fast.BUT THE MEDIUM MOVIE , WHAT CAN IT OFFER.?The story should be the star and the rest should be a means. So I can't give it more than a 5.Sometimes during watching it I thought Sion Sono was giving Hollywoos the big middle finger. But now a couple of days have passed and I Realize he was trying to make the most of it. In the past he would have just shot it. Take the pay heck and work on his own projects.ANYWAY. To the credit of the producers it does seem that Sono had enough freedom to put his stamp on the movie. And instead of joining the list of movies I have to rate a 1. It passes with a 5. And that is really surprising.Do yourself a favor and watch his other movies. The ones he has written himself.
Go watch the movie Pig. So much of a better Nicholas Cage vehicle. I found myself on a Nick Cage tangent, and decided to take this movie for a spin. Deeply regret it.
Admin should add an option to score less than 1 star rating what a trash movie.Guys don't watch this crap it is time wasting.... for Nicolas it is now normal to work in low rating movies.

Some of the one-liners were cheesy enough to make me laugh, so whatever.... it was OK - hence my 5 star rating.The story was kind of dumb, but I went along with it.It's a 5-star movie, nothing more, nothing less.

reviews.review_title: An EXPLANATORY Note, a Noble Intent
reviews.content: This seems foreign because it IS. I think this is the Asian version of Hades or Purgatory. A beautiful version of it, in parts. Out of time and odd motions, and especially the mindless sycophantic obedience of the women all push the Asian "envelope" of acceptable stylisms in modern culture. We Americans occasionally forget others think quite differently, have different aims, dreams and iconography.---Many cultures regard loud clapping and certain chanting scares away evil spirits.---Women are brought up to believe they should not look directly into the eyes of a man or a camera but I saw a few really try to do it. That's really BRAVE.--- These Evil Spirits are Portrayed to show lack of membership in an approved clan or group. To be without a clan is a kind of Asian hell on earth, ultimate punishment. Individualism is frowned upon.The characters in the loose "mummy" wrappings are GHOSTS. This is what kids have nightmares about. Also the body horror mannequins whose "skin" lifts out. That's what provokes an Asian night terror.This is all meant to start a conversation about what frightens and provokes another culture. And starting the conversation is what ART IS FOR. Yes, it's sloppy in parts, I think he ran out of money, time or permits. Or covid season was approaching.This deserves at least a 6 for Noble Attempt.
This movie is so bad that I had to post this review. Stretchy long unnecessary lengthy scenes. Slow speed bad story. Do not waste your time watching this. This is the worst Hollywood movie I watched.

reviews.review_title: Pretty Good but Not for Everyone
reviews.content: Let me be clear, I don't mean it's not for everyone with any kind of condescension, it's just that The Prisoners of Ghostland leans more towards the surreal then it does towards a typical Sci-Fi Action flick. And, I think, it would be perfectly reasonable for someone to expect that, especially with Nicolas Cage and Sofia Boutella in it.Trust me. It that's what you are looking for, Prisoners of Ghostland will be a disappointment. I think that is reflective of many of the low rated reviews here.Plot wise, essentially, it is a kind of "Escape from New York" set in a dystopian future resembling a mash up of Japan and the Old West. Nicolas Cage plays, "Hero," a bank robber allowed at a chance of freedom if he finds a man's granddaughter. The man is called the Governor and runs a bizarre future town that has saloons and bordellos with gunslingers, geishas, and samurai. The Governor is played by Bill Moseley, doing every bit his best to channel his inner Dennis Hopper.So, Hero is imprisoned after a bank robbery gone horribly wrong, and to regain his freedom he must find the Governor's granddaughter as I mentioned.This dystopian future appears to be Japan, but there is no rhyme nor reason that I could detect why there is a Western styled town with gunslinging cowboys in it. There are a lot of fun set pieces and colorful geishas that might wear some people thin, but I found entertaining. As, Hero heads out into the wasteland, we later learn there was a nuclear disaster that created the dystopia. He goes on a few adventures before finding the granddaughter, played by Sofia Boutella. Each adventure is a little stranger then the last and is reminiscent of the film Road Warrior. If you try to follow the film as a straight narrative, you'll most likely get bored and/or irritated. But, if you watch it, with a sense of fun and let go and some of the more surreal elements, it can be just that. Fun.Since the film's strength relies on its visual elements, it's a little hard to describe each scene and I don't want to spoil anything. Safe to say, Hero, does make it back to see the Governor and that's where the Prisoners of Ghostland has its explosive climax.The film's director Sion Sono also directed the films, Why don't You Play in Hell? And Suicide Club. More accessible, in my opinion, but also on the strange side. I didn't realize, at first, that he was the director.This film aside, I must admit, I'm really enjoying seeing the journey Nicolas Cage is taking as an actor. Definitely hit or miss, but it's fun to see what he'll be in next.

For those that criticise this and say negative things, go back to watching main stream rubbish.This is wonderful and Nicholas Cage is great.Possibly his most bizarre yet, and as one reviewer commented, "What Did I Just Watch" ... Yeah !!!Enjoy !!! And make up your own mind.Check out Mandy and Willy's Wonderland too.

reviews.review_title: Not worth the time, or mental anguish
reviews.content: Imagine you attend a party filled with your partners friends and coworkers, the setting is interesting and the people full of energy. You try to be a part of the evenings conversations, but the guests only speak to each other via a series of inside jokes, and hold spoken tales of places and events you've never heard of. That would be a less frustrating version of the story that PotG lay out for us.The direction given to the actors plays like notes given over a koren war era handset, and then poorly related thru a beta version of google translate.The visual elements of the film, while making almost no sense in the greater scheme of things are interesting to look at, and is a welcome change to paying attention to the acting going on.In fairness, i managed to get only 60 minutes into the film, somehow they have another 45+ minutes to go. If i do revisit the film at a later date, either seeking closure or when I hit a peak of masochism, the film will be on mute and the subtitles will be off.
Its bad.... so bad that i regret spending time to wath it.....even more paying for it. Cage is on quite bad string of movies right now an i want bother to se his next one.

reviews.review_title: Reconcile that post nuclear bombs, a culture saves itself by adopting US heroes
reviews.content: This film is really a commentary hidden in an absurd action adventure.The commentary is about how absurd it is that a culture devastated by nuclear destruction, living in fear of nuclear annihilation, will simultaneously adopt the hero worship of the opponent culture and pray for the bombers to become the saviors.

I was turned off by even giving Prisoners Of Ghostland one a try after seeing all the negative reviews. I had already watched the well rated Cage movies Mandy and The Color Out Of Space (which had much higher ratings than this), but did not like them at all. After seeing numerous reviews complaining that Prisoners was incoherent, my main criticism of the two previously mentioned films, that was it.Then, the movie became cheaply available, so I said WTH, I'll give it a try- expecting the worse.I would not call this movie excellent, I added 2 stars to my 6 star rating- because I don't want people to miss out on an entertaining film. But it is a pretty fun movies to watch. There is a lot of fun visuals, absurd humor, a premise sort of Mad Max-esque, and Nicholas Cage being Nicholas Cage. Funny enough, the plot/story is far from incoherent, and in fact is pretty conventional.

reviews.review_title: Kill Bill meets a Wild Wild West fever dream
reviews.content: I'll make this short, I personally was fascinated by this movie. To the average person, it is complete nonsense, my family was relieved for it to end. There's so much to ponder and interpret throughout the experience. I look forward to watching more films from this director.

reviews.review_title: I strangely enough enjoyed it and they made it work.

If you want something easy or b-bad Cage for Friday night, this isn't it. This requires your full attention. I can't really say what exactly it is that doesn't make me want to give a higher score, probably that it is too unexplained by the end of it. Some openings are fine, often the best, but this entire movie is up to interpretation and I do have mine but I can't help but wonder what more exactly the filmmakers intended for us to experience and take with us?

So go with me on this.

After a prison bus crashed into a truck filled with nuclear waste, a big chunk of Japan was written off and is a lawless wasteland, with one town – Samurai Town — being ruled by The Governor (Bill Moseley) who has a harem of so-called granddaughters as his slaves. All around his small town is what they call the Ghostland, a place where the radiated scum of the Earth live and die and kill. When Bernice (Sofia Boutella, Gazelle from Kingsmen: The Secret Service and Jaylah from Star Trek Beyond), one of the granddaughters, goes missing The Governor makes it Hero's (Nicholas Cage, again the California Kinski of weird roles in stranger movies) job to rescue her.



Through movie fate, Hero's old partner was Psycho (Nick Cassavetes), a man who will fill anyone in his way and was the cause of the accident which destroyed most of Japan. And then one of his balls explodes.

Yes, Prisoners of the Ghostland isn't your normal movie. It's directed by Sion Sono, who also made Suicide Club, Tokyo Tribe, Why Don't You Play In Hell?, Tag and so many more wild movies over the past few years.

Sono has called Wild at Heart his favorite Nicolas Cage movie and one of his inspirations while saying that Cage was "The easiest person I ever worked with, brought me back from the dead."  That's because the film was delayed a year after the director had a heart attack.

As for Cage, he's referred to this as the wildest movie he's ever made. My jury is out on that one, but this movie looks, feels and acts as odd as its star and trust me, I wouldn't have it any other way. A gang of mutants against angry women and Cage with a sword, one arm and one testicle? I know what side I'm on.

Prisoners of the Ghostland ...a film by Sion Sono starring Nicolas Cage...equal parts post apocalypse, zombies, samurai, westerns, kink, the plotline form escape from new york, boredom, and at least one musical number...this is what happens when a director spins a wheel of madness and has no concept of what a bad idea would be.   Is there a good story? no.  Is it entertaining? sometimes.  When it lands its a visual masterpiece (a sword fight to time in the bottle) but most of the time it feels like someone showing you 5 minutes of a random anime.   So you get lots of beautiful cherry blossoms, moving hu-mannequins, and Nicholas Cage running around holding a testicle.  it is not for most viewers but if you start you may have a tough time looking away.  For me it's more weird than good...2 stars out of 5 (yet I am glad I watched)

Nicholas Cage is EXCELLENT, as usual. But he can't save this film.  People are trying to stop a disaster by pulling on the hands of a town clock with a rope.  (Can you say "morons"?)
There is a bank that has tons of money, so it gets robbed, even though this is an apocalyptic world where money is of no value to anyone. 
The Japanese girls are all cute. But how they wound up in the American West is a real riddle. (Maybe they could base a movie on it, huh?(
I think the big problem is the director had no clear vision of what he wanted, so he wandered from scene to scene (Like someone in a place called "Ghostland" maybe?)
The photography is excellent. The costumes are excellent. The town is excellent. The premise for the film is excellent. There just isn't enough logical narrative to hold it all together. It kind of looked like a Steampunk Convention where everybody was drunk. 
But Nicholas Cage still did a fine job. He's a great actor, but there just isn't much here for him to work with.  (He was excellent in the movie "Pig" as well, but just like this one, there wasn't much narrative material for him to support his efforts.)

All questions.  I'll give this my best shot: this is about a hardened criminal (Nicolas Cage) in Japan.  He has been captured and presented with a deal for his freedom from the Governor (Bill Moseley): put on a bodysuit with explosive devices a la The Suicide Squad and bring back the Governor's granddaughter (Sofia Boutella).  This will be a challenge because she has gone to the Ghostland, which is a place that nobody can leave once they enter.  So this is one that made me excited.  The trailers looked to be over-the-top, and they even put on a quote from Cage on the poster: "The wildest movie I've ever made."  Armed with excitement, I bought my ticket with friends.  Boy was I disappointed.  I want to say that I made an earnest effort with this, and I was on board for the setup.  Bill Moseley is doing his best Colonel Sanders impression, and he lays down all the rules, firmly establishing the running clock involved and the dire consequences if not met.  Even though I couldn't tell what to make of where this movie was headed, I was here for the premise and the tone.  Then the story proceeds to aimlessly drift for the next hour.  I thought we were about to get into a time-sensitive action thriller that would keep the tension taut, and I don't understand why they emphasize the countdown if they never planned to follow through with it.  Once we get to the Ghostland, it just stops making sense.  It is weird for the sake of being weird, and you can only show me so much random imagery before I start to grow numb to it.  I don't know if this is a positive or a negative, but they don't explain how any of this works.  Sure, they'll take a break in the middle to give you a literal slide show on what happened in the past, but they never establish any rules to this world, so there are no stakes.  No stakes mean no reason to care, and I don't blame the entire row in front of me in the theater for bailing at the hour mark.  I just wanted a crazy Nicolas Cage action movie, but any action is few and far between.  In fact, I would even go to say that Cage is underutilized in this movie.  This random samurai (Tak Sakaguchi) is given more to work with than Cage, and it's not a lot.  I was thankful that Cage was there since he is doing his standard wide-eyed performance, which was enough to keep me awake.  The writing and the pacing make Prisoners of the Ghostland D.O.A.
I now know what it feels like to drop acid…..

When you're on laced shrooms and bad LSD at a Burning Man festival in a Japanese desert. That was director Sion Sono's vision, and he did not disappoint putting it on film.

However, having actors-turned-wannabe-writers Aaron Hendry and Reza Sixo Safai with barely to no writing experience come up with this screenplay, was wackadoodle. I got annoyed with the number of production companies displayed in the opening credits, you'd think at least one would've invested in a seasoned writer to at least look over the final script. Safi and Hendry wrote a bunch of incoherent, convoluted, plot-hole and technical-issue riddled nonsense.

The 103 min runtime, sub-par pacing, and many long dragged out and unnecessary scenes, made this film seem like it was 3+ hours long.

Luckily, with Sono's directing and Sohei Tanikawa's near-perfect cinematography, the eye-candy sets, crazy costumes and props, and stunning visuals kept me hooked. The score was fitting and on point. The casting and performances were excellent, especially Nicolas Cage (who this role was made for) and Sofia Boutella.

It's a shame no one babysat the writers, as this could've easily been a cult classic. But as is, I'm thinking this would've been a much better music video backdrop for Pink Floyd or Metallica album. It's a very generous 6/10 from me.
Just Don't waste your time with this movie.

"Prisoners of the Ghostland is everything a film starring Nicolas Cage is expected of being. Possessing technical attributes of making the biggest Hollywood studios shamelessly hide with envy, Sion Sono's movie is as illogical, absurd, ridiculous, stupid, and insanely entertaining as I hoped it would be. By mixing up dozens of distinct genres, the straightforward premise gets sucked into a world of total anarchy, where samurais, cowboys, nuclear explosions, modern cars, and much more collide to surround an otherwise simple narrative with nonsensically hilarious storylines and awesome action sequences. Sofia Boutella and Bill Moseley help Cage tackle this chaos, but the latter is the absolute standout due to his remarkable experience in crazy films. Despite it occasionally crossing the line and becoming too much for me to manage - it becomes seriously confusing - as long as the viewers are well-prepared to accept every jaw-dropping new development, fun is guaranteed with this brilliant satire."

I thought this was insanely fun, and really beautiful and weird to look at.  The storyline is incomprehensible at times, but there are some hilarious lines, and the overacting worked in context for me.

If Sergio Leone had taken one of his scripts, had a Japanese writer tweak it up, hired Japanese cast and crew, then put Nicolas Cage in the Clint Eastwood role, this would be the result. As far as I know, it's the first Post Apocalyptic-Samurai-Western movie, with zombies. It's self-awarely fantastic and silly.

The story, a classic quest, could be told with pilgrims, knights, samurai, cowboy drifters or death row inmates. This is a bizarre and visually compelling treatment, with interwoven noh drama, perhaps Greek chorus, narrating the back stories. Beautifully executed, great individual performances, and an altogether fresh look at a story thousands of years old. It's what you go to the movies for.

Words cannot do justice to how bad this film is. A discount Mad Max on acid is the only description that comes to mind. Nicholas Cage's wooden acting and painfully obvious hair dye just put the finishing touches on it. In mitigation, the dialogue is so awful that noone alive could do anything with it. As an example, I present the actual line he comes out with when threatened: "I'll Karate chop you". You have been warned.

I can get behind full on art house, or on the flip side a fully coherent story, but this film tries to balance in both and it fails horribly. Very poor directing, which leads to poor acting (although we do get the wacky and wild eyed Cage but it felt out of place and forced) and some god awful slow parts that led to some people walking out and some falling asleep around me. I do study martial arts but am no master, and feel confident I could’ve easily choreographed all the fight scenes at a much more entertaining level. It all just felt so flimsy, clumsy, and downright dumb. There were some beautiful looking set pieces that just became bogged down by poor use. I do like Nicolas Cages’s late game acting pursuits and respect him for taking on all these obscure, fascinating, wild movie roles. However this mess of a movie is no Mandy, and could easily be passed over and forgotten, falling into that realm of worst movies ever made.
Sono and Cage fan but this is unintelligible, uninvolving, and unreedemable. Sono misfires completely.
If 'Pig' was a step forward for Nicolas Cage? 'Prisoners of the Ghostland' is a step too many back.

rt_summary: In the treacherous frontier city of Samurai Town, a ruthless bank robber (Nicolas Cage) is sprung from jail by a wealthy warlord, The Governor (Bill Moseley), whose adopted granddaughter Bernice (Sofia Boutella) has run away. Strapped into a leather suit that will self-destruct within five days if he doesn't find the missing girl, the bandit sets off on a journey to find the young woman -- and his own path to redemption.
